Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: Materials for Renewable Energy NaturE's Way (RENEW)
Award.AbstractNarration: This PIRE project will address the global challenge that many of the materials used in today's clean energy technologies come from unsustainable sources. While often thought of as only substitutes for liquid fossil fuels, biomass substances can serve as replacements for non-sustainable building blocks in many applications. PIRE: RENEW will use biological-based materials to create sustainable replacements and improve material performance in high value-added, high performance applications, beginning with solar and wind energy devices. Research will explore applications where intermolecular and interfacial interactions play a key role in self-assembly and aggregation, in building structural materials with exceptional properties, and in nanoscale optoelectronics. A wind track will investigate building blades from biobased nanocomposites, while a solar track will explore structure-property relationships of cellulose nanowhiskers, bacterial cellulose fibrils, and sophorolipid surfactants. The program will produce replacements that improve function, provide renewable sources, and mitigate environmental impact in production and disposal. Case Western Reserve University and the Polytechnic Institute of New York will lead the international research nexus necessary to provide these ongoing material solutions and to educate future materials scientists and engineers. Partnerships include the University of Pennsylvania, Rochester Institute of Technology, and universities in the U.K., Brazil, Belgium, and Italy. Together, they provide expertise in synthesis, processing, characterization, theory, and lifecycle analysis needed for this global problem. Under them, twelve U.S. graduate students and postdocs, alongside international peers, will be trained in sustainability problem solving. Broader impacts will include materials innovations applicable outside energy (e.g., consumer products) and a sustainable materials website. The project is funded by NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE) through the PIRE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PIRE- Materials for Renewable Energy NaturE?s Way (RENEW) award was designed to address the global challenge of using biological-based materials to create sustainable replacements and improve material performance in high value-added, high performance applications for clean energy technologies: solar and wind power. The results of this project have been the development of renewable biobased thermoset resins and renewable cellulose based reinforcement to replace the traditional materials used in wind turbine blades. Moreover completely bio-based adhesive and coatings were also developed.

 

Ultrathin nanoporous cellulose mats exuded by bacteria were shown to provide antireflection properties that could lead to more efficient solar cells.  When these mats were filled with liquid crystals, they could form electrically controllable transparency devices that could have applications in electrically controlled windows for energy efficiency and privacy.  The bio-based manufacture is low-cost, sustainable and highly scalable. The structure of self-assembling bio-based optoelectronic materials were shown to be finely tunable using combinations of nature-based molecules.  These materials could form the basis of a new class of highly manufacturable semiconductors for solar energy.

 

The award provided opportunities of training for a large number of graduate and undergraduate students. Not only were these students trained in science and engineering, but they also were able to participate in a three-year summer program to develop an appreciation of a sustainable lifecycle, including the associated economic variables.  They also explored methods to translate research into a small business opportunity. Some of the students had the opportunity to travel abroad and learn new communication methodologies for collaboration that spans time and geography. They learned the value and importance of diversity in an international context: not only working across cultures, but also working across race and gender.

Modified by: Ica Manas-Zloczower
